user.biography: National Geographic Explorer and NY Times photographer, creating an aerial perspective on climate change and global food supply @feedtheplanet

node.text: End of a night of fishing for shrimp with in shallow waters near Kochin, India.  The fishermen spend the night on these small platforms perched in the shallow seawater.  They lift the cantilevered net up a few times per hour to remove their catch, before lowering and throwing in more coconut shells to attract the small crustaceans.  This night of fishing brought in 5kg of shrimp, which will fetch about 500 rupees ($7) in the local market.

node.text: Fresh fish are a luxury item in parts of the world without refrigeration, and dried fish are much easier to store and transport, as seen in the fish drying works of Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh. Baskets of small fish are carried ashore in headloads, then brought to the drying racks on handcarts. Bangladesh is heavily dependent on mariculture, and more than 80 percent of its dietary protein is derived from fish, much of it dry.

node.text: Salmon farm near Ålesund, Norway, with 200,000 Atlantic salmon in each of eight pens.  The fish are fed from a barge via tubes that spray pellets of fish meal, fish oil, and soy beans into the water.  No antibiotics are used, but some colorants are added to the food to give their flesh the orange color typical of wild salmon.  The fish average 18 months in the pens and gain approximately 1 kg of wet body weight for every 1 kg of dry food.  The fjord is 220ft deep underneath the pens, and goes to over 1,500ft in the center, allowing the fish excrement to become widely distributed with the tidal action, while the fjord protects the pens from wind and wave damage.  After each generation of fish the pens are left empty for six months to be cleaned and reduce the risk of diseases and parasites.  This farm is owned and managed by MOWI, the biggest grower of farmed salmon in the world, with approx. 20% of market share.

node.text: First light on Béni Isguen, the most traditional village of the M'Zab region of the Algerian Sahara.  The oldest buildings in this 11th Century hill town were constructed using local stone, plaster, and wood from palm trees.  The streets here are footpaths just wide enough for people and donkeys, as city is designed for community living within a defensive environment.  The hill is crowned by a minaret that once served as a watchtower, while providing storage for both grain and arms.

node.text: First light on Isla Pabellon, a volcanic islet at 12,800 ft. in the Salar de Uyuni.  The island has been terraced with ancient shore lines from wetter times when the Salar was a salt lake trapped between to branches of the Andes. At that time, the islet had a shape similar to a coral atoll.  From #DesertAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.

node.text: Migrating mega-dunes of Sossusvlei, Namibia.  The Namib is one of the oldest deserts in the world, as indicated by the color of the sand on the inland side of the dune field. The beach sand of this coastal desert starts out white, but after some 50 million years of sun, wind, and morning dew, the sand grains have traveled some 40 miles inland and taken on a deep orange hue.  From my first book, #AfricanAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio

node.text: Fishermen in the Colorado River Delta of Mexico must battle 30 ft. tides during full moon. This was once one of the richest fisheries in North America, but has been greatly degraded by water diversions and over-fishing. Tremendous spring floods once inundated the delta annually, but an intensive network of dams and irrigation projects in the 20th century turned this once fertile area into almost sterile sand flat.

node.text:
Fishermen off-loading their catch through the surf in Nouakchott, Mauritania. 
The official catch in Mauritania is 900,000 tons, but reconstructed catch estimates are more than 2M tons/year. This pelagic fishery has been migrating northward some 5° (300NM) every 10 years for the past few decades due to changing sea temperatures, and increased fishing pressure.

node.text: Transplanting Del Monte Gold pineapples on a  plantation near Buenos Aires, Costa Rica.  Pineapples are somewhat primitive plants that can transplanted by placing base of their spikey crowns in the soil to start a new plant.  Del Monte has 230 sq mi of of pineapple, banana, and melons in Costa Rica, and keeps 26% of it in a wild or re-wilded state, providing biological corridors for wildlife and buffer zone for watersheds.

Photo by George Steinmetz in Buenos Aires, Alajuela, Costa Rica. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and text that says '©2021 George Steinmetz'.

node.text: Harvesting pineapples on a plantation in the foothills of Costa Rica.  The Del Monte Gold variety was developed here 25 years ago, and has become the dominant commercial variety worldwide, tripling U.S. pineapple consumption over the past two decades, due to its sweet, less acidic flavor.  Each fruit is picked by a hand ($40/day for a 10 hour shift), before being chilled for shipment by containerized boat to markets in N. America, Europe, and the Middle East.  Due to its unique geography, these foothill plantations are only a few hours from both Pacific and Caribbean ports, allowing Costa Rica to provide almost half of the global supply of pineapples.
